website_summaries.verdict: A popular drill that boasts quality and performance. Unless you need an entire kit, strongly consider this one.
pros: A drill-only kit that can save you money
Drill is lightweight yet rugged with the precise torque of the Brushless Cordless kit
cons: The drill doesn't include a lithium battery or other extras

website_summaries.verdict: Makita is renowned for quality, and this budget-priced model reflects that. It is your best choice if you want a quality drill that is also affordable.
pros: Lightweight with 18V of power and ergonomic build
Brushless motor provides ample torque and reasonable battery life
cons: May occasionally lock in hammer mode

customer_reviews.title: Only useful as a hammer drill
customer_reviews.text: General contractor here. I own many Makitas and this is the only one that's trash. Lots of motor power for its size but it gets stuck in hammer mode. Only useful as a hammer drill. Others have mentioned this same issue so no point sending it to Makita to be repaired as its clearly a design flaw and not a defect. This model needs to be redesigned and Makita needs to recall this.

customer_reviews.title: I have several Makita cordless tools and they have worked ...

customer_reviews.title: Useless after 5 - 30min jobs.

customer_reviews.title: Failed head, stuck on hammer drill mode
customer_reviews.text: I push these hard turning large hole saws, etc. I've cooked the brush type. This one is brushless and the battery/motor combo is awesome. Some redesign is needed on the head. Once it fails that's it. You may get it back to screw/clutch, but unlikely. I dismantled for a look, since I got my money's worth out of it. The hammer feature is based on a pitted surface riding ball bearings. The ball bearings are no bigger than 1/8". They wear out, then come free internal, interfering with mode operation. It is a consumer tool. I got 2 years for $60 tool only. Not bad but I'm having a hard time buying another. Meanwhile I'm cutting holes in hammer mode.
customer_reviews.author: Plumbob

customer_reviews.title: The chucks kind of crappy
customer_reviews.text: My drill doesn't get stuck in any particular mode but the chuck slips when I try to tighten a bit into it. It's a ***** to loosen now to remove a bit. Been using it for multiple applications in the solar industry for about 8 months now. (wood hole saws, concrete hammer drilling, metal carbide etc.) Outside of that still drills like a beast. I think it's a matter of time before it craps out. Maybe I'm over tightening the chuck? Can someone enlighten me?

Also works fine as a power screwdriver or nut driver with easy torque adjustments. Wish it had a level on top like my old drills but that is not necessary. Happy with my purchase but you will have to look to other reviewers with experience with different brands and decide for yourself.

The bigger batteries are available if I ever need longer single use. I debated getting the smaller subcompact LXT model line with the lower torque. After getting this and using it I'm happy with this model. The size isn't much bigger than the subcompact and there is a lot more torque when I need it.

customer_reviews.text: Pretty powerful and it has a lot of features. I use Makita exclusively in my line of work and they get a lot of abuse. However after the first use this one locked up on me so that I couldn't change it from the Drill to Hammer To Screw feature. I didn't want to break the damn thing all the way since I could still use it but my coworker used a large amount of force to move it away from the Hammer setting and it has freely moved between the three settings ever since. So it doe the job but that still makes me a bit wary of what may happen next.

product_meta.title: Makita XPH12Z 18V LXT Lithium-Ion Brushless Cordless 1/2" Hammer Driver-Drill, Tool Only
product_meta.description: Style:Bare ToolMakita is the innovation leader in Brushless motor technology, and the 18V LXT® Brushless hammer driver-drill (XPH12Z, tool only) combines power and run-time for more drilling, driving and fastening tasks in wood, metal, and masonry. The efficient Makita BL Brushless motor is electronically controlled and engineered for longer run time, increased power and speed, and longer tool life. The variable 2-speed Brushless motor delivers up to 2,000 RPM and 530 in.Lbs. Of max torque for efficient fastening. It weighs only 4.2 pounds (with battery) with an L.E.D. Light that illuminates the job area for applications in dark spaces.

The electronically-controlled BL Brushless motor efficiently uses energy to match torque and RPM to the changing demands of the application
